li.title: \nth[(i,j)] entry of a matrix
li.p: the entry in the \nth[i] row and \nth[j] column of a matrix

li.title: size (or dimensions) of a matrix
li.p: the number of rows and columns in a matrix, usually written m \times n to mean m rows and n columns

li.title: equal matrices
li.p: matrices with the same size, and the same numbers in corresponding entries

li.title: matrix addition
li.p: the new matrix obtained from two old matrices of identical sizes by adding corresponding entries

li.title: scalar multiple
li.p: the new matrix obtained from an old matrix obtained by multiplying every entry by the same number k; the common scale factor k is called a scalarscalar

remark.p: We will encounter the geometric origin of the word scalar in .

li.title: zero matrix
li.p: a matrix where every entry is zero, written \zerovec

li.title: column vector
li.p: a matrix consisting of a single column

li.title: row vector
li.p: a matrix consisting of a single row

li.title: vector of unknowns
li.p: a column vector containing all of the variables in a system

li.title: vector of constants
li.p: a column vector containing all of the constants from the right-hand sides of the equations in a system

li.title: square matrix
li.p: a matrix with the same number of columns as rows

li.title: main diagonal
li.p: the diagonal of entries in a square matrix from top left to bottom right

li.title: transpose
li.p: the new matrix obtained from an old matrix by turning rows into columns and columns into rows; we usually write \utrans{A} to mean the transpose of the matrix A
